ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course was great for re-introducing me to college level math courses. I had been out of school for a few years before taking this and this was a great course to get back into the right mind-frame.
My knowledge of calculus was deepened and just of problem solving in general.
I learned how to think critically about mathematical concepts, and apply the concepts from this Calculus class to relevant areas in life.
Calculus
I learned time management skills and how to study for a test.
I learned to evaluate integrals of functions in many ways. Starting from simpler approximations, the complexity of the material deepened throughout the course, but each part was built from the last.
I learned to learn a lot of concepts on my own, due to the explore system.
I gained knowledge of integral calculus and knowledge of power series, sequences, Taylor series and polynomials, and polar coordinates/curves/area and parametric curves.
I learned how to reach out for help when I need it by going to peer tutoring.
Developed calculus skills and took them to a deeper level than reached in high school.
Developed fundamental understanding of calculus.
Greater insight on calculus
Time management

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths of this course are that the instructors are really well knowledgeable and good at teaching. The one big improvement that the course could benefit from is removing the tests or at least changing them. Timed test taking in an unfamiliar location is so unrealistic to the real world, you are never going to need to apply these topics in such a setting outside of school. I think it is an unnecessary source of stress for students and a poor judge of understanding of the material.
No weaknesses that come to mind. It is taught in a good way.

This course could be improved by making the material taught between sections more similar. I have heard from my peers in other sections that their Teaching Assistant teaches more/less material, or even that they are teaching it completely differently. This creates a disconnect when all students end up taking the same exam. There should be a more centralized teaching curriculum to create more continuity between classes.
I wish we had more problems on our problem set because I felt like we didnt engage with some topics with as much depth. Felt a bit fast paced overall.
The class is not very collaborative, which I think would help with grasping topics.
I think the teachers are not all equally good at teaching, which is obviously totally normal, but I could tell at the review sessions that some were really good at explaining and others werent.
It was well structured although the instruction was a little light compared to professor dierhtorn

Strengths: Lots of access to peer tutoring for problem sets and general questions

Weaknesses: Course was taught somewhat detached, class was not very interactive
The pace varies from very fast some weeks to rather slow smoke others; more streamlined process would be better. I really liked the Canvas explorations.

Explorations should be due after class, rather than before. While I appreciate the idea behind having them due before class, with no prior exposure to the concepts , they became tedious and frustrating. I think they would be more effective functioning to consolidate new material after it is taught in class.

The class is well structured.
More in depth teaching of individual topics would be useful. Some topics felt skimmed over.

Strength: One of this course's strengths is that it is taught in smaller sections instead of one large lecture. This makes the lecture easier to engage with and makes office hours more productive. 
Weakness: The class moves very quickly, and problem sets do not always line up with what was taught in the lecture.
I don't find it that much engaging

Strength: well organized
Weakness: n/a

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No one recommends math classes just for fun.
This course is not as daunting as it may first seem. It is a fine class.

I would recommend this course to another student just because it is essential that you know how to use certain integration strategies and find area between curves. The infinite series and sequences I could've done without.
Yes, because the topics are engaging and the course itself is very well organized.

Yes. Especially if you have taken AP calc in high school, it is a good building block and doesn't go through concepts too quickly. The psets are manageable and the tests are often less difficult than the homework problems.
Yes, I think its a fair math class and I think it makes sense to take this if you plan on majoring in the STEM area.
If you have to take it as a prerequisite, yes. Otherwise, if you're looking to fulfill a QR requirement and willing to put in the work, it's not too bad.
I would recommend it to any student that wants a solid foundation in math.
It wont inspire you or change the way you think but it will teach you some calculus.
Yes - interesting course, decent execution. Calculus as a whole is a topic that all people should be familiar with.
Yes, if you want to learn calculus II. The class is well organized, and the workload is not too high.
Yes
